metadata.titleEn: Flux observation dataset over a winter wheat-summer maize rotation cropland in the North China Plain - Weishan (Gaoying) flux site of Tsinghua University (2005-2006)
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the fluxes and meteorological data of Weishan (Gaoying) flux site of Tsinghua University from May 17, 2005 to September 26, 2006. The site (116.0542° E, 36.6487° N, 30 m above sea level) was built on March 18, 2005 and is located in Xiaozhuang Town, Chiping District, Liaocheng City, Shandong Province. It belongs to Weishan Irrigation District along the lower Yellow River. The local climate is characterized as temperate monsoons, with an average annual temperature of 13.8 ℃, an average annual precipitation of 553mm, most of which occurs between June and October, and an average annual potential evaporation of 1950mm. The soil type is silt loam. For the soil of the top 5 cm, the average saturated soil water content, field capacity and wilting point in volumetric values are 0.43, 0.33 and 0.10 m3m-3, respectively. The height of the flux tower is 10m, and the area within about 1 km radius around the flux tower is largely homogeneous winter wheat-summer maize rotation cropland. The winter wheat is generally sown in mid-October and harvested in early June of the following year, while the summer maize is usually planted directly into the stubbles of wheat at the same location immediately after the harvest of wheat and is harvested in late September to early October. See the file named “Supplementary data_WeishanGaoying20052006.xlsx” for specific sowing, harvesting and irrigation dates.
The surface flux data is measured by the eddy covariance system, which is composed of a three-dimensional sonic anemometer (CSAT3, Campbell Scientific, Inc., Logan, UT, USA) and an open-path infrared gas analyzer (IRGA) (LI-7500, LI-COR, Inc., Lincoln, NE, USA) with an installation height of 3.7m. The 30-minute net ecosystem carbon exchange (NEE), latent heat flux (LE) and sensible heat flux (H) data were obtained after the raw 10Hz data were processed by Eddypro software. The preprocessing steps included despiking, double coordinate rotation, 30-min block averaging, time lag compensation, spectral corrections, the Webb-Pearman-Leuning (WPL) density correction, a quality check using the “0-1-2 system”. Then the 30-min data were screened as follows: (1) remove bad quality fluxes with quality flag 2; (2) limit H and LE to - 200 ~ 500 W m-2 and - 200 ~ 800 W m-2, respectively; (3) the data during the precipitation events were excluded. Then, REddyproc software is used to filter the data under low turbulence mixing conditions (i.e. filter the flux data according to the friction wind speed u*), fill the gaps in the time series, and then the NEE was divided into ecosystem respiration (Reco) and gross primary production (GPP) by the nighttime partitioning method.
The published dataset includes: year, month, day, time, atmospheric pressure (P), infrared surface temperature (Tsurf), wind speed (Ws), wind direction (Wd), air temperature (Tair) and relative humidity (rH) at 2m, downward short wave radiation (Rsd), upward short wave radiation (Rsu), downward long wave radiation (Rld), upward long wave radiation (Rlu), Net radiation (Rn), incident photosynthetically active radiation (PAR_dn), reflected photosynthetically active radiation (PAR_up), precipitation (precip), groundwater level (GW), 5cm/10cm/20cm/40cm/80cm/160cm soil water content (soil_VW_ 5cm / 10cm / 20cm / 40cm / 80cm / 160cm) and soil temperature (soil_T_5cm / 10cm / 20cm / 40cm / 80cm / 160cm), soil heat flux at 5cm depth (soil_ G) , raw data of net ecosystem carbon exchange (NEE_raw), raw data of latent heat flux (LE_raw), raw data of sensible heat flux (H_raw), net ecosystem carbon exchange after gap filling (NEE_ f) , latent heat flux after gap filling (LE_f), sensible heat flux after gap filling (H_f), ecosystem respiration imputation (Reco_f), gross primary productivity (GPP_f). The data are stored in .xlsx format at 30-minute intervals. Null values in the dataset are represented by NA.
Please refer to Lei and Yang (2010a, 2010b) for detailed information of this site and the observation instruments.

background: Evapotranspiration is a major component of the energy and water balances in agricultural ecosystems. Understanding the seasonal and interannual variability in evapotranspiration and energy partitioning, based on the long-term measurements of fluxes, is important for identifying weather, soil water, and crop factors which regulate fluxes at different temporal scales, and is vital for modeling crop production and water balance. The North China Plain, the largest agricultural production area in China, is a water-limited region. More than 50% of the nation’s wheat and 33% of its maize production is grown on this plain, through a wheat/maize double cropping system. However, the area is experiencing serious water shortages, primarily due to the high water consumption by the agriculture sector through crop transpiration and soil evaporation. Extensive irrigation not only increases evapotranspiration and reduces runoff, but also decreases sensible heat flux. Evaluation of the basic characteristics of evapotranspiration and energy partitioning in response to irrigation is therefore helpful in identifying the effect of irrigation on regional water and energy balances in the North China Plain. The eddy covariance technique (EC) is generally considered to be a highly suitable method for providing direct and trustworthy flux measurements.
research objective: The main objectives were to examine the seasonal and interannual variations in evapotranspiration in terms of relevant controlling factors (weather, soil moisture, canopy conductance), and to quantify the seasonal and interannual distributions of evapotranspiration (latent heat flux) and energy partitioning.
challenges: Thus, it is difficult to evaluate the causes of energy imbalance at this site. Measurement error of the EC system, representation of the measured soil heat flux, horizontal energy advection, energy used in photosynthesis, and energy storage in the canopy and top soil could all contribute to energy imbalance (Foken, 2008; Li and Yu, 2007; Meyers and Hollinger, 2004).
methods: In the present study, we used three years of consecutive measurement data, covering the period from October 2005 to September 2008, to analyze variations in evapotranspiration and energy partitioning in this region. A 10 m-high tower was erected for mounting flux and meteorological instruments. The EC system was placed 3.7 m above the ground. Wind velocity and virtual temperature fluctuations were measured using a three-dimensional (3D) sonic anemometer. The sampling frequency of the EC system was 10 Hz. Hydrometeorological variables were recorded at 10-min intervals on several data loggers. Air temperature and humidity were measured at 1.6, 3.6 and 6.0 m above ground level. Downward and upward solar and longwave radiation and photosynthetically active radiation (PAR) were measured at 3.5 m above ground level. A tipping bucket rain gauge was mounted at 1.5 m above the ground. Wind speed and direction were measured at 10.0 m above ground level. Soil temperature and soil water content were measured at 0.05, 0.10, 0.20, 0.40, 0.80, and 1.6 m below the ground. Soil heat flux was measured at 0.03 m below the ground. Groundwater level was measured using an automatic water depth sensor installed in a groundwater well close to the tower. The half-hourly latent and sensible heat fluxes were calculated by computing the mean covariance of water and temperature fluctuations with the fluctuating vertical velocity observed by the EC system. The TK2 software package was employed for the quality assurance and quality control (QA/QC) of the EC data.
dataset: Using the eddy covariance technique, three years (October 2005–September 2008) of water and energy flux measurements were obtained for a winter wheat/summer maize rotation cropland in the North China Plain.
findings: Seasonal variability in ET was primarily explained by the variations in equilibrium evaporation (ETeq) and canopy conductance (Gs). On an annual basis, latent heat flux accounted for about 59% of the net radiation, suggesting that more energy is partitioned into evapotranspiration in this agroecosystem site.

Definition.Question: What is the eddy covariance technique in the context of agricultural flux measurements?
Definition.Answer: The eddy covariance technique is considered a suitable method for providing direct and trustworthy flux measurements in agricultural ecosystems. It involves measuring wind velocity and virtual temperature fluctuations using a three-dimensional sonic anemometer, and hydrometeorological variables are recorded at intervals. This technique is used to analyze variations in evapotranspiration and energy partitioning by calculating the mean covariance of water and temperature fluctuations with the fluctuating vertical velocity.

Definition.Question: What challenges are associated with measuring energy imbalance using the eddy covariance technique?
Definition.Answer: Challenges in measuring energy imbalance with the eddy covariance technique include measurement error of the system, representation of measured soil heat flux, horizontal energy advection, energy used in photosynthesis, and energy storage in the canopy and topsoil. These factors can contribute to difficulties in evaluating energy imbalance at an agricultural site.

Comparison.Question: How do data collection techniques using the eddy covariance system compare to other methods in measuring evapotranspiration and energy partitioning in agricultural ecosystems?
Comparison.Answer: The eddy covariance technique is considered highly suitable for direct and trustworthy flux measurements, providing detailed temporal data on evapotranspiration and energy partitioning. It involves measuring wind velocity and temperature fluctuations to calculate heat fluxes. Other methods may not offer the same temporal resolution or direct measurement capabilities.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways do hydrometeorological variables and flux measurements aid in understanding the impact of irrigation on regional water and energy balances in the North China Plain?
Interpretation.Answer: Hydrometeorological variables and flux measurements provide insights into how irrigation affects evapotranspiration, reduces runoff, and alters sensible heat flux. By evaluating these impacts, researchers can better understand the role of irrigation in modifying regional water and energy balances in water-limited areas like the North China Plain.

Causal Consequence.Answer: The implementation of advanced data processing software, such as Eddypro and REddyproc, could enhance the quality and reliability of flux measurement datasets by facilitating the identification and correction of errors, ensuring the removal of poor-quality data, and providing robust methods for data interpolation and partitioning of fluxes.

Causal Consequence.Answer: Extensive irrigation in agricultural regions like the North China Plain could lead to increased evapotranspiration, reduced runoff, and decreased sensible heat flux, affecting the regional water and energy balances, as the energy partitioning is heavily influenced by irrigation practices.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives behind collecting and analyzing evapotranspiration and energy partitioning data in agricultural ecosystems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The main objectives are to examine the seasonal and interannual variations in evapotranspiration in terms of relevant controlling factors such as weather, soil moisture, and canopy conductance, and to quantify the seasonal and interannual distributions of evapotranspiration (latent heat flux) and energy partitioning.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to address measurement errors and energy imbalance when using the eddy covariance technique for flux measurements in agricultural research?
Goal Orientation.Answer: It is crucial to address measurement errors and energy imbalance because they can affect the evaluation of energy balance at the site. These errors may arise from several factors, including the measurement error of the EC system, representation of the measured soil heat flux, horizontal energy advection, energy used in photosynthesis, and energy storage in the canopy and top soil.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the significance of employing the eddy covariance technique for long-term data collection in the context of water-limited agricultural regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The eddy covariance technique is significant as it provides direct and trustworthy flux measurements, which are vital for understanding seasonal and interannual variability in evapotranspiration and energy partitioning. This understanding is critical for identifying factors regulating fluxes and modeling crop production and water balance, especially in water-limited regions like the North China Plain.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the critical steps involved in ensuring data quality and accuracy when measuring evapotranspiration and energy fluxes using the eddy covariance technique?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The critical steps include preprocessing the raw 10Hz data using Eddypro software, which involves wild point identification and removal, averaging over a 30-minute period, two-step coordinate rotation, spectral correction, and WPL density correction. Quality control is performed by removing poor quality fluxes, limiting H and LE values to specific ranges, and excluding data during rainfall. Further data filtering is done using REddyproc software to remove data under low turbulence conditions using friction velocity (u*) filtering.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can researchers address the challenges of energy imbalance when using the eddy covariance method for flux measurements in agricultural ecosystems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Researchers can address the energy imbalance challenges by considering measurement errors of the EC system, ensuring accurate representation of soil heat flux, accounting for horizontal energy advection, considering energy used in photosynthesis, and accounting for energy storage in the canopy and topsoil. These factors are crucial for achieving a balanced energy budget in flux measurements.

Enablement.Answer: Data processing software like Eddypro and REddyproc enhances the quality and reliability of flux measurement data by performing tasks such as filtering low turbulence conditions, gap filling, and applying corrections like WPL density and spectral corrections.
